Comment: For actual sane takes from a vaccine skeptic long before vaccines were as safe and normalized as they are today, you can look to Benjamin Franklin.  > “In 1736, I lost one of my sons, a fine boy of four years old, by the small-pox, taken in the common way. I long regretted bitterly, and still regret that I had not given it to him by inoculation. This I mention for the sake of parents who omit that operation, on the supposition that they should never forgive themselves if the child died under it: my example showing that the regret may be the same either way, and that, therefore, the safer should be chosen.”  In 1736 I wouldn’t have judged anyone harshly for being a vaccine skeptic. They were still new fangled and there were real risks associated with them. Now almost 300 years later… none of that remains true.
